div1.head: Jim to M. Paul Rockwell April 27th 1915
div1.p: Andrew our director is out here to day and I can get a letter back to you uncensored. He brought out your appreciated letter and the photos to me. They’re great mon vieux, eh? Let me know the damage.

Well I’ve been in it and came out O.K. The French, preparing for a violent attack in le Bois la Pretre at Pout a Mousson, detrained train loads of troops at our base. I was on
duty here at Dieulouard when the shells began coming in. The nearest to us was 30 yards. They were very high explosive shells and raised hell. Seventeen people were wounded and there was a call for two ambulances. Willis and I volunteered. The crowd watched us from the tower of an old castle and the people yelled “du bon chance” as we went down the street. My blesse was in a factory at
the side of the track they were shelling. I got my car across the sidings but couldn’t make the main line. I had to stop and cross over to the house. A shell sizzed [sic] down about 75 yds off and let go with the hell of a crash bagging a soldier behind a wall. A group of men were inside the house crowded against the wall. Another obus came in and they ducked. The poor
mangled ouvrier was soaking in blood on the mattress. No one would help me carry him. Finally an old man said he’d show me the road around to the door. We ran up the tracks to the station. A shell hole was just in front. The blooming thing hadn’t gone off. We passed the gare and made a turn of the factory and I was at the door. I loaded the man in and got back to the hospital.
Willis brought in two. One of his, a young man died last night. Mine may live. That makes four killed and 27 wounded in five days. So you see we’re getting what’s coming to us. We’ll have a worse time when they pull the big fight at Pont a Mousson where we go in shifts of 5 cars each. The God damned Boche could pot us with rifles there if they wanted to. For the love
of Mike don’t tell anyone about what I’ve written to you unless generally, for if it got to the authorities the whole works would be recalled. The Germans shelled until five this morning. They will probably start in again this afternoon.
Give my love to Mlle. Guerin when you see her and tell her to drop me a line.

I’m sorry your
fiancee has been delayed in her return to Paris.
Glad you’re getting off some stories and I know they’ll make good as hell.

I rather like the outfit here, but I’m tired of all this damn military stuff, saluting about 16,000 times a day and answering fool questions for soused soldiers. About half the town remains pickled all the time and grabs one around the neck saying: “Come with
me to Le Bois le Pritre and we’ll kill the Boche.[“] I’ve been on my good conduct, tho [sic] I indulge in the most excellent beer we have here.

closer.salute: My best old war horse, and here’s hoping.
